header.title: Sacked model: 'All white people benefit from racism' - BBC News
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: A transgender model, sacked by L'Oreal after claims she posted racist comments online, has stood by her view that 'all white people benefit from racism'.. But Munroe Bergdorf told the Victoria Derbyshire programme her original Facebook post had been taken out of context.. Watch the BBC's Victoria Derbyshire programme on weekdays between 09:00 and 11:00 on BBC Two and the BBC News Channel.. . Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog. . World In Pictures https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list.... Big Hitters https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list.... Just Good News https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list...

replies.commentText: As an Asian, it appears to me that blacks harbor the greatest vocal animosity, and without much merit. However, regarding this issue, I believe it originally lies in the deterioration of our education system. For over a millennia, Trivium and Quadrivium had produced a long line of some of the wisest, virtuous, and intellectually competent men in history. From Emerson, Schiller, Goethe, Kant, Descartes, Spinoza, Swedenborg, Carlyle, Nietzche, Addison, and so forth. This tradition, and the intellectual atmosphere it created was what enabled and propelled mankind out of the medieval ages, into an era of enlightenment and innovation. But in the 1800s, the industrial revolution changed the entire dynamic of progress of Europe and the Americans. Education previously was a long and difficult process, requiring many years of strict cultivation. It is no exaggeration to say that the middle school equivalent back then was what post graduate degrees would be today. Despite this, it was greatly beneficial. However with the industrial revolution looming and booming, many families sought the promise of better pay and employment in the city. They moved in droves, crowding the streets and amplifying the financial and political power of big companies. Most families did not see the pertinence of spending money for an education, when they could simply send their young children to factories, often with dangerous machinery. This became the popular trend. As families became somewhat more financially stable, their numbers grew, increasing the world population. Few generations in, quality education was dying, while general ignorance was extremely common. As it happens, ignorance and cultural shifts go hand in hand. We enter the early 1900s and we see the "party generation" aka the roaring twenties, and subsequently more and more people, raised in the cities, who support materialism and sensuality more then spiritual and intellectual growth. It wasnt until the 1950s that people started dealing with civil rights, women equality, and other social matters. Along with the rise of "hippies". But these people, intellectually speaking, understood little of such affairs, much like today. Ironically, Trivium and Quadrivium was legally pushed out of the curriculum in the 1900s as well. As you may know, education in the modern era is commonly the rote memorization of facts, the crowding of the intellect. An education that does not instill critical thinking, but "what" to think, aka indoctrination. Not to mention "Tests" were often similar to trivia. How does this all tie in to your original post? Well today, such circumstances have set the foundation where there are increasing controversies and issues that revolve around social causes. From racism, to politics, t o gender equality, to g>ay rights, etc. But majority of people do not have an education that sufficiently enables them to think logically. They move towards emotions, and habits that result from being emotionally biased. As you k now, racism is commonly a heavily misappropriated term thats lost all logical significance. Its become a buzzword/scrapegoat to deflect and blame an other race or party, putting them under social scrutiny and avoid serious and rational discussion, especially given most of them are incapable of doing so. This is but one example. But above all... "democracy dies in darkness", in other words, the quality of a democratic society is only as a proficient and just as their education enables them to be. As we have seen, it has become deficient in many regards. This ignorance has let SJWs and other less desirable groups spread their ignorance and hatred into what it has become today. All the while continually benefiting off white innovation and progress, though I hate to phrase it like that. In summary, this ignorance is what is enabling anchor babies, illegal immigration, and racial disparity to run so rampant. The election of incompetent people, and the constant pandering and giving in to left leaning groups is the cause of the fall of western culture. Imo, refugees and southern immig rants, African americans, and the Chinese, are currently your worst enemies. China especially has been utilizing every immoral deceit and legal/illegal trickery to suck money off the west. Their whole society was built on theft, copying, and mass underpaid labor. Their society embodies the extreme of everything that is wrong and superficial. The best anyone as an individual can do, is train ones moral and intellectual disposition. Assume the intellectual heritage that forwarded mankind out of darkness. And hopefully, enter a position of power, fighting against the ignorant and unworthy elected.

As a white guy who lived in Memphis (I stayed at the jobcorp facility 300 students only five of us white) I faced what they call micro aggression and what I call confusion. As I talked to my fellow students ,who have in some cases never even met a white person before(Memphis is heavily segregated), I heard some of the most ludicrous things. I was told "I thought all white people came from money" (my family has been living below the poverty line for generations). When telling some of my friends that I missed my grandmas beans and cornbread or hamhock and collard greens, I was met with looks of shock and the remark that "you eat that? I thought y'all only eat white people food." To which I wondered what the hell white people food was. I took a course at a trade school there and they had a barber class giving free haircuts. Went in to get one and everybody stopped what they were doing and looked at me like I was a leprechaun. The instructor asked me what I wanted which was a simple shortening and she had me sit down. She then pulled out scissors which I said wouldn't Clippers be easier? To which she told me "you can't cut white folk hair With Clippers" which made me laugh cause my mah has only ever used Clippers and same with my dad(marine Nam vet). Before she started cutting she called the class over and had them sit in a full circle around me really close because "they ain't ever cut white folk hair before so you will be an excellent lesson". I sat there as these black students sat there either feverishly writing notes or staring in wonderment in a thinker like pose. On a rare occasion I was able to sneak off campus and go get a beer or something and I was told many times by my black friends "bro you cant go into that hood your a big white guy with glasses and a polo they are gunna think your rich you will be an instant target" I never cared tho cause I'm from west side san antonio and grew up in the hood so I can take care of myself. I did almost get jumped several times but again i know how to handle myself. The point of this story is I never saw it as some form of subverted aggression or ever thought they wer e racist, I knew that it was simply confusion towards a race they never had the opportunity to socialize with, Thats all it is. Anybody who preaches this microagression garbage is do ing nothing more then promo ting racism and ignorance and it's going to cause damaging affects. America has came a long way sinc e him crow but with more people acting like this it's running the risk of bringing us all back to the day s when racism actually was rampant.

We don't like to admit it, but imbedded deep into our cognition is a judgement program running on auto-pilot and our senses serve this evolutionary purpose. And yes, those senses include visual. So within seconds of meeting someone every single one of us is making judgements: sex, height, weight, facial expression, posture, clothes, social hierarchy AND skin color. Any/all forms of systematic oppression should be avoided and combated, but we won't further the conversation by entering an oppression competition. We are all born with, and into, different privileges and misfortunes and must strive, on an individual basis, to leverage our strengths and mitigate our weaknesses, however we deem necessary, again on an individual basis.

@Random Guy ok. I was waiting for this. African's actively fought against the slave trade. What you are speaking on is chattel slavery. African Slavery by Europeans was it's very own evil. That benefitted the entire world, despite active resistance b y African nation's and their Kings and Queens(1470 - 1800). This fight was foughy in their homeland, on the seas, and in America. There was continuous resistance against Europeans during every phase of the slave trade. Because the rebellions of t he African slaves increased, the slave traders created laws designed to red uce African resistance.  The information we have on on the resistance to slavery came from written documents kept by the European sailors. There is enough information, including historical facts, examples of resistance, and dislike of the European slave trade, to establish that the enslavement of Africans was not accepte d by African peop le.  African leaders and those opposing the European slave trade, organized and assigned large groups to keep watch for slave ships traveling to the East and whose crews were well-known for kidnapping Africans on the coast. For example, King Ansah of Ghana (1470-1486) had the Fante people watch for European ships, and prevented them from coming ashore. Many other African leaders did not permit Europeans in their kingdoms. In Benin, the people had heard of the intentions of the Europeans, so they killed them as soon as they came ashore. There were some kings who agreed to trade with the Europeans, but attempted to stop it once they saw the problems that were created in their lands. Through the tactics of several African leaders and kings, they were able to minimize the European slave trade but they could not stop it completely. The treachery and greed of the Europeans, hurt the African economy and, therefore, damaged trade r elations. African King Nzenga Maremba tried to stop the slave trade in the Congo only after he originally participated in the trade in exchange for military items and support from Portugal. King Maremba agreed to r elease his African prisoners of war to the Portuguese who wanted the best (1470 - 1800) young African men as a bargaining chip to be sure the King kept his word. The Portuguese promised to train and educate the young men to become priests and later to return them to the Congo. King Meremba let the Portuguese convince him to take the Christian name, Alfonso, as a show of support. When Alfonso asked for the return of a few of his former prisoners, who had been trained to serve as physicians, surgeons, pharmacists, assistants for shipbuilders and carpenters, his requests were denied. After having his requests denied several times, King Alfonso learned that his prisoners of war had been sold as slaves in Portugal. In 1526, King Alfonso wrote to King John III, the former King of Portugal, and asked for his help in ending the slave trade in the Congo. He explained the freedoms that were given to the Portuguese, who had set up shops, become merchants in the Congo and had amassed fortunes. The people in the Congo could not do the same because they had complied with the agreement and now did not have the same abundance of wealth as the invaders. King Alfonso related that the damage was so great that his people and land were being seized daily. King Alfonso ended his letter to King John III with another request for his help because it was the will of the people in the Congo and other kingdoms that there should not be any trading of slaves nor markets for slaves.  Other countries that were resisting the slave trade throughout the continent of Africa were Senegal, Ghana, Benin, Ni geria, and Angola. In 1777, King Agadja, a Dahomean monarch, captured an Englishman and his slave raiding party who had entered his kingdom looking for more Africans. The Englishman and his crew were released after they promised to return all the Africans they had captured. King Agadja gave the Englishmen a warning to take to the rulers of England, that if any other slave traders were sent to his Kingdom, or other kingdoms, they would be killed. In 1787, the Senegal King of Almammy, passed a law that made it illegal to take enslaved Africans through his kingdom. To let (1470 – 1800) Europeans know how serious the law was, the king returned the presents French slave traders sent as bribes. Queen Nzingha of Angola fought a successful 30-year war against the slave traders of Portugal until the Portuguese negotiated a treaty with her in 1656. Their treaty remained in effect until she died in 1663. P.S. But your history books don't have that😏. Why? They are anglicized versions of revisioned history.

commentThread.commentText: I agree with much of what she is saying of course but... What I find frustrating is that the following is so often missed in identity politics: There are multiple hierarchies of power in society, and while yes they concentrate as they accumulate in any given individual. ...In actuality they rarely all parallel in any given individual. So, on an individual level, many individual people of colour are far better off than many individual white people and many individual gay >people are better off than many individual straight people etc. Yes all these group dynamics are very important to be aware of and to fight against, but we cannot lose the narrower lenses of social understanding and compassion either, in favour of always looking at the biggest ones. +biscuitsalive She's referring to systemic racism, not the kind of one on one racism (of one person against another). If you live in Europe or the US, it is not possible for you as a white person to be the victim of systemi c racism. However, if you lived in Chad or Saudi Arabia, you definitely could. Many on here want to straw man her argument by leaving out the 'systemic' part of the comment. System ic racism is comparable to the difficulties that left handed people face in a world designed for people who are right handed. Most right handed people have not consciously set out to create a world that favours righties, however, this does not change the fact that right handed people have an advantage in the environment they live in (a small percentage of left handed people die because of accidents related to their handedness). It's not a completely flawless analogy, but I find it is a useful way to take the emotion out of the argument to understand the nature of the problem. It's also worth noting that the impact of syste mic racism also has a direct affect on the self-image of minorities of certain communities (i.e. how black people see themselves). See the doll experiment for more information [LINK]

What we disagree on is the label used to describe these inherently aggressively capitalist organisations. These have arisen partly as the result of an impotent government unable to vet these enormous organisations, whose activities often fall outside of the country's jurisdiction. How do we ensure that they function to serve the will of the people? What confuses me is the characterisation (or implication) of this enormous capitalist, free market motivated machines as 'socialist'. I agree these organisations exist. I also agree they are a problem. The question is what do we do about it? What mechanism would we have that could stand up to these organisations? What impact has Brexit or Trump had on reversing these enormous global empires, many of which exist outside their country's laws? Let's take a hypothetical: If Texas decided to raise its tax on companies then a large national corporation could simply move its main base of operations across state lines. That way, it can evade those aggressive tax laws and move to another state which is more favourable towards the 1%. The only way that you can ensure this company (we'll call it BigCorp) doesn't take jobs out of Texas but pays reasonable levels of tax is to introduce state wide legislation. However, statewide legislation means that states are now bound together in a way they were not before. This analogy attempts to show the dilemma of globalisation (and perhaps the more recent Brexit debacle). Long gone are the days when a single country can stand up to such a corporation because they can simply move to another country.

I don't normally quote entire paragraphs, and I freely admit that the source material is not the best. However, I think it's fitting as a response to your internet claim: 

Long before the technology existed to actually build the Internet, many scientists had already anticipated the existence of worldwide networks of information. Nikola Tesla toyed with the idea of a 'world wireless system' in the early 1900s, and visionary thinkers like Paul Otlet and Vannevar Bush conceived of mechanized, searchable storage systems of books and media in the 1930s and 1940s. Still, the first practical schematics for the Internet would not arrive until the early 1960s, when MIT's J.C.R. Licklider popularized the idea of an 'Intergalactic Network' of computers. Shortly thereafter, computer scientists developed the concept of 'packet switching,' a method for effectively transmitting electronic data that would later become one of the major building blocks of the Internet (Evans, 2013) 

Otlet was belgian, Vannevar Bush was american, and Tesla was Serbian. 

Whilst it is certainly true that inventors and mathematicians who happened to be British made significant contributions to our modern internet, your statement would seem to be a moral conclusion based on hasty generalizations. Since we do not have access to a parallel universe where the British empire never existed and, hence, the impact this would have on the technology of Human civilization is at best unknown; we can say with little authority what that world would look like. 

There is a difference between romantic notions of science and reality. Science tends to be a collaborative effort with multiple contributors, and influences (without Einstein's theory of relativity, we wouldn't have GPS on our Sat Navs and the clocks on our mobiles phones would be inaccurate); discoveries tend to be built upon those of previous generations. 

The multiple discovery theory tends to reject the romanticised heroic theory of invention and discovery, which ignores the countless examples of simultaneous scientific and mathematical discoveries throughout history. For example, the 18th-century discovery of oxygen by Carl Wilhelm Scheele and Joseph Priestley or the simultaneous evolutionary models of Darwin and Russell (Wiki, 2017). It's interesting to note that messages sent into space by NASA and SETI (Search for extra terrestrial intelligence) often include basic scientific and mathematical principles, signifying a belief by some, that much of our science and maths is innate, whose discovery, by an intelligent, sentient species capable of traversing the stars, is inevitable. Do we know for certain that if Edison were never born the light bulb would never have been invented? (He wasn't the only person to claim this invention). And, what would Great Britain look like without the centuries of Roman influence? 

Your countryman, Jimmy Savile, raped and abused hundreds of children but raised millions to make the lives of many significantly better. Does one cancel out the other? A crass example, but apt for this discussion.
